paper_metadata.title: MAIN TEXT
paper_metadata.extraction_summary: The paper describes the A19D variant of the TTR gene, detailing its clinical significance, patient information, penetrance data, and functional implications.

individual_records.phenotype_details: severe cardiac impairment, neuropathic pain, numbness, tingling, balance abnormality
individual_records.evidence_sentence: The patient was first seen at the University Hospital of the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, at CEPARM (Centro de Estudos de Paramiloidose Antônio Rodrigues de Mello; http://ceparm.com) on March 2012 with a history of sensory complaints in the extremities since 2009 as characterized by neuropathic pain, numbness, tingling and balance abnormality.
This patient has a brother with the same mutation, who underwent cardiac transplantation as a consequence of severely compromised cardiac function.

functional_data.summary: The A19D variant is predicted to decrease the thermodynamic stability of the TTR protein, leading to increased amyloidogenicity.

variants.segregation_data: The A19D variant segregates with disease in the family.
variants.population_frequency: Not found in the data bank (http://amyloidosismutations.com/)
variants.evidence_level: Moderate evidence based on clinical presentation and familial segregation.
variants.additional_notes: This is the first description of the A19D mutation in Brazil.
key_quotes: As far we know, this is the first description of a patient with the A19D mutation in Brazil.
Interestingly, the patient we found in Brazil is of Sweden-German origin, originally from the State of Santa Catarina (south Brazil), which is a state with a large Germanic community.

extraction_metadata.notes: All relevant data regarding the TTR variant A19D was successfully extracted.
